titleStmt.title: Bridge Phase 4: Witness fThomas, Collation unit C10

availability.licence: Distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License

div.p: How can I describe my emotions at this catastrophe, or how delineate the wretch whom with such infinite pains and care I had endeavoured to form? His limbs were in proportion, and I had selected his features as beautiful. Beautiful!—Great God! His yellow skin scarcely covered the work of muscles and arteries beneath; his hair was of a lustrous black, and flowing; his teeth of a pearly whiteness; but these luxuriances only formed a more horrid contrast with his watery eyes, that seemed almost of the same colour as the dun white sockets in which they were set, his shrivelled complexion, andand straight black lips. And the contortions that ever and anon conpulspulsvulsed & deformed his un-human features.

Like one who, on a lonely road, Like one who, on a lonely road,
Doth walk in fear and dread, Doth walk in fear and dread,
And, having once turn’d round, walks on, And, having once turn’d round, walks on,
And turns no more his head; And turns no more his head;
Because he knows a frightful fiend Because he knows a frightful fiend
Doth close behind him tread*. Doth close behind him tread*.

div.p: This was the commencement of a nervous fever, which confined me for several months. During all that time Henry was my only nurse. I afterwards learned that, knowing my father’s advanced age, and unfitness for so long a journey, and how wretched my sickness would make Elizabeth, he spared them this grief by concealing the extent of my disorder.the extent of my disorder.the violence of the attack. He knew that I could not have a more kind and attentive nurse than himself; and, firm in the hope he felt of my recovery, he did not doubt that, instead of doing harm, he performed the kindest action that he could towards them.
